4 A student investigates the refraction of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
Refraction is the change in direction of a ray of light when passing into a transparent substance, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 918, 167]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the concentration of a gel affects the angle at which light is refracted when passing from air into the gel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 918, 214]]<|/det|>
A transparent gel block can be made by dissolving gel powder in hot water in a mould and allowing it to cool. Changing the amount of powder will change the concentration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 242, 427, 261]]<|/det|>
Concentration is measured in \(\mathrm{g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 399, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 869, 322]]<|/det|>
- samples of gel made at different concentrations and labelled with those concentrations - a ray-lamp which produces a narrow ray of light.
